          <!-- Convert Encoding from SHIFT-JIS to UTF-8 -->
          <script language="javascript" type="text/javascript">

         <span id="newsListing_newsList">

          <br/>
          <div id="newsListing_newsList_RadMultiPage1">
           <script src="/WebResource.axd?d=cj4HjcRlG6yn_V2cv-cL9cKG1zBVA0ukVd-JI-AXij3ClCSr6KaH3tDAxTNxf_Y_-3N60SOJ4NePM5gWxRnc1hVPIcvQ5kTHfc-nQrp7RNqxSGv87gCZhYQ3lqKVCk9y0&amp;t=633645865770000000" type="text/javascript">
           </script>
           <div id="newsListing_newsList_ArticleContent">
            <span class="NewsHeadline" id="newsListing_newsList_lblHeadline">
             PHRASES THE JAPANESE LOVE TO HATE
            </span>
            <br/>
            <span id="newsListing_newsList_lblDate">
             Dec 27, 2011
            </span>
            <br/>
            <br/>
            <span id="newsListing_newsList_lblArticle">
             <span id="tmpPasteIE1325002191446">
              <p class="MsoFooter" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal">
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">
                 <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                  By Rochelle Kopp, Managing
                  <st1:place w:st="on">
                   <st1:city w:st="on">
                    Principal
                   </st1:city>
                   ,
                   <st1:country-region w:st="on">
                    Japan
                   </st1:country-region>
                  </st1:place>
                  Intercultural Consulting
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </span>
               </b>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-SIZE: 14pt">
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 10pt">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 In working with Japanese, I find that a few key phrases tend to come up again and again as being aggravating to them.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 They tell me that they hear these phrases frequently from their non-Japanese colleagues, particularly Americans.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 On the face of it, these phrases dont seem to be so terrible, but how they are interpreted culturally by Japanese is what makes them so irritating.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Readers of this column may read this and think oh no, Ive said those things a million times.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 If thats the case, better late than never to start avoiding these phrases!
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="TEXT-DECORATION: underline">
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                  Its not my job
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 A Japanese colleague asks you to help him with technical information about Product A.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 But you work in Administration, and thus are not familiar with the technical details of the Product.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 You tell him its not my job.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 You may have meant this as a simple statement of fact, but if the conversation ends there, your Japanese colleague may view this as indicative of a bad attitude on your part.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Because to Japanese ears, its not my job sounds like Im not interested in helping you.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 This interpretation takes place because Japanese feel that any employee should be willing to respond to any request that is made of them.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 This relates to the fact that in
                 <st1:country-region w:st="on">
                  <st1:place w:st="on">
                   Japan
                  </st1:place>
                 </st1:country-region>
                 , employees do not have specific job descriptions, and in many cases may not have specific job titles.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Japanese join a company, rather than take a job, so that they have attitude of being ready to do whatever the company might ask of them, whatever is needed at the moment.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 For example, its possible to see department heads making copies or sending faxes  its work that needs to be done, and there is no sense of these tasks being not their job.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Due to this pitch in wherever needed attitude, when a Japanese individual is asked a question, they feel obligated to try and help as much as possible.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 They arent apt to draw a boundary around what they will or wont do.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 This is considered good customer service, or helpfulness among colleagues.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Thus, used to anyone they ask a question jumping to help with it, many Japanese are taken aback when someone turns down a request because its not my job.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 You may validly feel that its not your place to help with the request, that you arent the most qualified person
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 or that its someone elses responsibility.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 However, its better not to end the conversation with its not my job.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Instead, do what you can to make sure the Japanese person asking the question is pointed in the right direction to get the answer.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Remember, the Japanese person may not know who is the right person to ask or how to get the information.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Thats why he asked you.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Hes relying on you to help him get what he needs done.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Thus, recommended responses would be:
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Im not the person in charge of that, but Susan is.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Please discuss it with her.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Thats not my area of responsibility, its Susans.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill call her and ask her to help you.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 I dont have the most experience in this area, Susan does.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 So I think Susan can help you more effectively.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Heres her phone number, please contact her.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 A similar phrase that is annoying to Japanese is I dont know
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 -- to Japanese ears it tends to sound like I dont care.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Similarly, even if you dont happen to know the answer to a question, its important to help the person find the answer or to steer him to someone who can.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 For example,
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Let me check for you.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill let you know in a few minutes.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 You can find that information on the xyz website.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Here is the address.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Susan knows a lot about that product.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Here is her phone number.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 How you respond to inquiries that arent necessarily in your main area of expertise or responsibility will make a big impact on how you are perceived by Japanese colleagues.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 When you get such a question, consider it an opportunity to show your helpfulness and usefulness.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Also, remember that if Japanese are coming to you with random questions, its a compliment to you because they see you as someone who can assist them.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Rather than looking at organization chart to see who is in charge of what, Japanese tend to take questions to people they are comfortable with and have been helpful and reliable in the past.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="TEXT-DECORATION: underline">
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                  No problem
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Americans in particular tend to use this phrase as a way of showing their confidence.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Its a sort of abbreviation of theres no problem I cant handle.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Dont worry, leave it to me!
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 But when Japanese hear this phrase, they take it as a promise that there absolutely will be no problems.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 So if later anything does go wrong, they feel that they have been misled.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 The key here is to avoid giving vague, optimistic assurances that will be taken literally by Japanese.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Instead of giving a simple no problem, give more details about how you view the likelihood of success.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 For example,
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 I dont anticipate any problems, but if anything comes up I will be sure to let you know.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 I think the likelihood of problems is low, but there is of course always the possibility that some problem will emerge.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill let you know if we encounter any potential delays.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Then, if there are any problems, be sure to let your Japanese counterparts know as soon as possible.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Another similar phrase that creates misunderstanding is I can do it.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 As part of the American can-do attitude and tendency toward optimism, when asked if they can do something, Americans often say yes, even if they dont have complete certainty that they can.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 In other words, they will say I can do it when the probability is more than 50%.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 In contrast, Japanese will not say I can do it unless the probability is over 95%.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 This can create misunderstanding when the Japanese interprets an American I can do it as a literal promise.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 To avoid this, the following phrases are recommended:
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 Im pretty sure I can do it.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill try my best.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 I probably can do it.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill work hard at it.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 This looks like something I probably can do.
                 <span style="mso-spacerun: yes">
                 </span>
                 Ill let you know how it goes.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <o:p>
                <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                </span>
               </o:p>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt">
                 These phrases lack the typical self-confident bluster that Americans tend to require from each other, and thus might sound weak or wishy-washy to American ears, but they are less likely to lead to misunderstanding when working with Japanese.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-SIZE: 14pt">
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <i style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal">
                <span style="FONT-SIZE: 11pt">
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                  <span style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt">
                   This article originally appeared in
                   <st1:country-region w:st="on">
                    <st1:place w:st="on">
                     Japan
                    </st1:place>
                   </st1:country-region>
                   Close-Up Magazine
                   <o:p>
                   </o:p>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                </span>
               </i>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-SIZE: 14pt">
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="MsoNormal" style="MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt">
               <span style="FONT-SIZE: 14pt">
                <o:p>
                 <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">
                 </span>
                </o:p>
               </span>
              </p>
              <p>
              </p>
             </span>
             <p>
             </p>
            </span>
            <br/>
            <br/>

            </div>
            <br/>
           </div>

           </script>
          </div>

            Back to Index
          </a>
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>

     </td>
